properties.name: 1877 Charles Knowlton's Fruits of Philosophy makes a scandle in London
properties.description: Posted by Vvkatievv London, EnglandOriginally published in New York in 1832, Charles Knowlton\'s pamphlet "Fruits of Philosophy" was the subject of much controversy when is was published and distributed in London in 1877 by Charles Bradlaugh and Annie Besant, resulting in their arrest for distributing obscene material. The pamphlet contained detailed descriptions of sexual biology (from anatomy to conception to fetal development), as well as suggested methods of contraception.

properties.name: 1877 Famines
properties.description: Posted by Vvkatievvnorth western province, indiaFamines in India around 1877 killed more than 6 million people, and were thought to have been caused by a mix of severe El Nino drought and severe oppression by British colonialism, or (the prevailing thought at the time by European intellectuals) overpopulation of the country. Famines in the rest of the world were cited as evidence of Malthusian disasters among European intellectuals and spurred the movement toward population control.

properties.name: 1879 Margaret Sanger was born
properties.description: Posted by Vvkatievv Corning, New YorkShe taught us, first, to look at the world as if women mattered. Born into an Irish working-class family, Margaret witnessed her mother\'s slow death, worn out after 18 pregnancies and 11 live births. While working as a practical nurse and midwife in the poorest neighborhoods of New York City in the years before World War I, she saw women deprived of their health, sexuality and ability to care for children already born. Contraceptive information was so suppressed by clergy-influenced, physician-accepted laws that it was a criminal offense to send it through the mail. Her crusade to legalize birth control spurred the movement for women\'s liberation, though her support of eugenics lead to criticisms of her cause and that of the organization that she founded- Planned Parenthood

properties.name: 1880 Marie Stopes born
properties.description: Posted by Vvkatievv Edinburgh, scotlandMarie Stopes was a paleobotanist, author, and social activist best known for her efforts in the early half of the 20th century to promote safe birth control for women. In 1921 Stopes opened Britain\'s first birth control clinic and, with the aid of second husband Humphrey Roe, she went on to found an entire chain of clinics with chapters in Australia, New Zealand, and South Africa. Marie Stopes was a passionate promoter of women\'s rights and women\'s sexual pleasure, and a staunch supporter of eugenics.

properties.name: 1886 Elise Ottesen-Jensen was born
properties.description: Posted by Vvkatievv norwayA vicar\'s daughter, Elise Ottesen-Jensen was the 17th of 18 children. Later in life, her father sent away her little sister Magnhild to give birth in Denmark, so that she could be forced to give up her child. Maghild was told nothing about pregnancy or birth, and for nine months she feared that her stomach would just split. She committed suicide because of the longing for the child she had to leave behind. For this, Elise could never forgive her father, and the fate of her sister became a strong driving force for her commitment to the struggle for women\'s rights. Elise Ottesen-Jensen was a Norwegian-Swedish sex educator, journalist and anarchist agitator, whose main mission was to fight for women\'s rights to understand and control their own body and sexuality. She was a member of the Swedish anarcho-syndicalist union Central Organisation of the Workers of Sweden. Her followers consider her a pioneer in the field of womens\' rights and feminism. She helped found the International Planned Parenthood Federation and her work made an impact on Gro Harlem Brundtland\'s political thinking, which has subsequently influenced United Nations policy and now the views of the World Health Organization as well

properties.name: 1893 Lady Rama Rau was born
properties.description: Posted by Vvkatievv Hubli, IndiaLady Rama Rau was president emeritus of the International Planned Parenthood Federation, and a longtime proponent of family planning. She was named president of the All India Women\'s Conference in 1946. In 1951, she founded the Family Planning Association of India and organized the first All India Family Planning Conference. Eight years later, she received India\'s highest civilian decoration for public service, the Padma Bhushan. Lady Rama Rau was named president of the International Planned Parenthood Federation in 1963, a position she held until 1971. She continued to serve as president emeritus of the organization until she died.

properties.name: 1897 Shizue Kato was born
properties.description: Posted by Vvkatievv Kyushu, japanShizue Kato, who has died at the age of 104, was the first woman to promote the birth control movement in Japan, much as Margaret Sanger did in the United States and Marie Stopes in this country. Her task was arguably more difficult than theirs. Unlike Stopes, she did not face religious opposition, but the militaristic regime in Japan during the 1920s and 30s was fiercely hostile to limiting the country\'s growing population, and, in educated circles, the subject was just as unmentionable as it was in England. The notion of a Japanese woman stepping out of her traditionally submissive role to take any social initiative was anathema to her family and friends. She was a courageous feminist campaigner for birth control and women\'s rights in Japan

properties.name: World's First Birth Control Clinic 1880
properties.description: Posted by Vvkatievv amsterdam, netherlands1880, Dr. Aletta Jacobs opened a free clinic for impoverished women, distributing birth control despite opposition
